pb p2 © pat gordon-smith special instructions why k3tog not k4tog in some row the original lace pattern uses only k4 decrease to decrease but for this scarf row 13 17 and 21 need k3tog at either end to hold the pattern across 51 stitches placing beads the bead is hooked on to the stitch you will knit/purl next using the crochet hook or other preferred tool a tutorial is available here https //debbieabrahams com/blogs/beading- techniques/hooked-in-beads achieving k3tog / k4tog after yo this is not easy because the yo tends to slip off as you are knitting the next stitches together to solve it use the method for knitting multiple stitches together shown in this video https //www youtube com/watch v=ji3ffpmmgcu then when knitting a row with k3tog or k4tog 1 don t do the last yo before k3tog or k4tog i e start the k3tog or k4tog immediately after the previous knit stitch 2 pass the first of the k3tog/k4tog stitches over the yarn laid on the left needle as seen in the video then pick up the strand that would have formed the yo circled in the photo below by passing the right needle under it from back to front see note next to image for advice on when to place the bead in row 9 and 21 3 complete the k3tog or k4tog by passing the remaining stitches over the yarn laid on the left needle and pass to right needle placing beads in row 9 and 21 notice the bead just left of the circled strand the written pattern instructions for row 9 and 21 show yo before pb to prevent the yo slipping off this bead was hooked onto the first of the stitches in the k4tog before it was passed over the yarn laid on the needle the yo is then completed as described in point 3 above © pat gordon-smith
